Award.AwardTitle: Imprints of New Physics on Cosmological Observations
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the research activities of Professor Savvas M. Koushiappas at Brown University.

Most of the matter in the universe takes the form of a mysterious "dark matter" which is unlike the familiar matter we deal with in our everyday lives. In the last few years, cosmological observations and laboratory constraints have shown that the nature of this dark matter remains elusive. Likewise, there have been many challenges to our understanding of the basic characteristics of the universe itself. As part of his research, Professor Koushiappas will attempt to understand the nature of dark matter and dark energy, explore new possible interactions between dark matter and regular matter, and attempt to study the cosmological and gravitational effects of dark-matter properties. As a result, research in this area advances the national interest by promoting the progress of science in one of its most fundamental questions: the discovery and understanding of physical laws. This project is also envisioned to have significant broader impacts. Professor Koushiappas will involve graduate students and advanced undergraduate students in this research, thereby providing critical training for junior physicists beginning research in this field. He will also give public lectures on his research results.

More technically, Professor Koushiappas will establish a research program to unite theoretical studies of the physics of dark matter with current and future cosmological observations. Bridging the gap between cosmology, astrophysics, and particle physics, Professor Koushiappas will use observations of the cosmic microwave background, the growth of structure and high-energy photons and other energetic particles to tackle fundamental questions about the nature of dark matter, the origin of the discrepancy in the accelerated expansion rate of the universe, the astrophysical effects of cosmology, and most importantly the interplay and connections between these different lines of inquiry. These goals will be achieved through sophisticated theoretical modeling and through the use of new and existing statistical and analysis tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project is centered around a research program to unite theoretical studies in dark matter physics and cosmology with current and future cosmological observations. This is done using observations of the cosmic microwave background, large scale structure, late developments in high energy particle physics and the interplay between these disciplines. 

The work performed during this funding period led to the following thematic research projects: 

The rate of expansion and growth of structure in the universe is governed by what the universe is made up-of, and our understanding of gravitational physics as described by the general theory of relativity. We explored motifications to the standard models of particle physics and cosmology in order to explain the observe discrepancy between measurements of the expansion rate and growth of structure that are made using data from the early universe (cosmic microwave background) and late universe (local measurements of the hubble flow).

Gravitation is the only force of nature that is not understood at the microscopic level. All other forces have a "quantum" description except gravitation. We explored ways that one can constrain theories of quantum gravity using late universe observations. Studies of this kind are important because they can potentially guide the theoretical work toward a quantum theory of gravity. 

One of the ongoing research areas in the identification of dark matter is the possibility that the dark matter particle is an ultralight scalar particle. Such spin 0 particles arise naturally in many theories beyond the standard model of particle physics, and are envisioned to solve many suspected problems on small scales (smaller than a kpc). We placed constraints on the mass of light dark matter and explored the formation history of the Milky Way as well as the possibility that dwarf galaxies may contain black holes. 

In an exploratory work we demonstrated  the successful application of neural networks in extracting an astrometric signal that is otherwise not possible. The demonstration was based on the astrometric signature of milky way dark subhalo based on weak gravitational lensing. A main development was the implementation of integrated gradients where we showed that one can go further than simply providing a statistical confirmation of the presence of dark subhalos, but also define localization vectors on the sky, thus enabling follow-up observations. 

The detection of a black hole merger events using gravitational waves led to numerous questions regarding the formation of this small black holes. We explored the possibility that one of the observed events contained a primordial black hole, and showed that this is impossible given the formation of baryonic black holes in the history of the universe. 

The project has implications not only in cosmology but in all of physics. Understanding what the universe is made up of (dark matter, dark energy, black holes, elements of the periodic table of elements etc.) is crucial in our comprehension of the physical world and of how we can use this knowledge to better and improve life. 

The project provided graduate student training. This training included extensive coding experience, both on small scales we well as high performance computing, writing scientific publications and presenting results in talks as well as disseminating results to the public. The depth and breadth of the graduate student training enabled the students involved to enter the workforce with the skills necessary for success in high tech STEM industries and academia.
